conclusion: We need to determine the velocity \( v \) of the conductor rod \( MN \) when it is moving at a constant speed using principles of mechanics and electromagnetism.

The rails \( AB \) and \( CD \) are vertical, connected at one end with \( DE \). The region \( BDE \) forms an isosceles right triangle. A uniform magnetic field \( B \) is directed perpendicularly into the plane of the rails. The conductor rod \( MN \) is horizontal and moves vertically while maintaining contact with the rails.
The effective length of the conductor \( MN \) in the magnetic field is \( l \).
The induced emf in the conductor is given by \( \mathcal{E} = B \cdot l \cdot v \).
The total resistance of the conductor \( MN \) is \( R = r \cdot l \).
The current in the conductor is given by \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} = \frac{B \cdot l \cdot v}{r \cdot l} = \frac{B \cdot v}{r} \).
The force on the conductor due to the magnetic field is \( F = B \cdot I \cdot l = B \cdot \left( \frac{B \cdot v}{r} \right) \cdot l = \frac{B^2 \cdot l \cdot v}{r} \).
The retarding force due to the magnetic field acts in the opposite direction to the motion of the conductor.

When the conductor is moving at a constant speed, the net force on the conductor is zero, so the retarding force due to the magnetic field is equal to the gravitational force: \( \frac{B^2 \cdot l \cdot v}{r} = m \cdot g \).
Solving for \( v \), we get \( v = \frac{m \cdot g \cdot r}{B^2 \cdot l} \).
The velocity of the conductor rod \( MN \) when it is moving at a constant speed is \( \boxed{\frac{m g r}{B^2 l}} \).
